text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN
- At least 32 people, including a 12-year-old boy, died and numerous others fell unconscious after drinking poisonous country liquor in Hyderabad city of southern Sindh province.
- A two-week ban was been imposed on pillion-riding across the Sindh province with immediate effect.
- A suspect arrested soon after the bomb blast in Lahore confessed to have carried out the explosion resulting in the death of 19 people, including 14 policemen.

- The splinter faction of Pakistan Peoples Party (Shaheed Bhutto) led by Ghinwa Bhutto and the Sindh National Front led by caretaker chief minister of Sindh province Mumtaz Ali Bhutto have sealed an electoral alliance for the February 3 polls.
- A fighter plane of the Pakistan Air Force crashed near Domeli village, about 20 km from Chakwal.
- Iran accused the United States of involvement in the bomb attack on an Iranian cultural centre in Pakistan, but said the incident would not affect relations with Islamabad.
- The mid-plan review of the Eighth Five-Year Plan (1993-1998) said gross domestic product grew five percent, the agriculture sector 5.9 percent and the manufacturing sector 4.5 percent.
- The Corporate Law Authority approved the prospectus of Saadi Cement Ltd, subject to certain important modifications, for offering 25 percent of its shares to the public.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- The government has decided to allocate licenses for the sale of liquefied petroleum gas by open auctions among pre-qualified bidders above a reserved price.
- Unexpected rains on Sunday have delayed shipment of rice export cargoes as the rice bags being loaded onto six vessels at the Karachi Port were dampened, exporters said.
- A pay-phone company, Telecard Ltd, said its service is likely to resume shortly after the government removed a ban on mobile, pager and pay-phone services in Karachi.
- A vessel carrying 18,000 tonnes of soyabean oil berthed at Port Qasim.
FINANCIAL POST
- A Federal Investigation Agency probe has proved that the state-run Saindak Blister Refining Project has run into snags due to heavy misuse of funds.
THE NEWS
- The U.S.-based oil company, Mobil Asia-Pacific, plans to start blending and packing of automobile oil from June as it has purchased the blending and packing plant of Zavier Petroleum.
THE NATION

- The International Monetary Fund is likely to decide on Tuesday whether to release the second tranche of $72 million credit facility to Pakistan before February 3 general elections or further negotiate with the next government.
- Former army generals have formed the National Raffa (welfare) Party, opposing any move to cut defence spending.
-- Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
